STAB52 - Introduction to Probability

By: Jaden Wang

Lecture 1

Question: Given a fair coin, what is the probability that it lands on a head when tossed?
Answer: 12\frac{1}{2}21​

Experiment: A process with an outcome. When the outcome is random, it is called a random experiment.

Let AAA be an event in a random experiment. Let rn(A)r_n(A)rn​(A) be the number of times (frequency) that AAA occurred in nnn repeated trials of the experiment.

The relative frequency definition of probability of AAA is equal to:
P(A)=lim⁡n→∞rn(A)nP(A) = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{r_n(A)}{n}P(A)=n→∞lim​nrn​(A)​

Sample space: The set of all possible outcomes in an experiment.
Examples:
Tossing a coin, S={H,T}S = \{H, T\}S={H,T}
Rolling a six sided die, S={1,2,3,4,5,6}S = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}S={1,2,3,4,5,6}
Tossing two different coins S={(H,H),(H,T),(T,H),(T,T)}S = \{(H,H), (H,T), (T,H), (T,T)\}S={(H,H),(H,T),(T,H),(T,T)}

Event space: Subsets of a sample space.
Note: {}\{\}{} is a subset of any set and so is an event (denoted by ϕ\phiϕ)
Note: A={1,2}A = \{1, 2\}A={1,2}

Notes:
AcA^cAc is the set of elements in SSS but not in AAA.
A∪BA\cup BA∪B is the set of elements in A or in B (or in both).
A∩BA \cap BA∩B is the set of elements that are in both AAA and BBB
A∩(B∪C)=(A∩B)∪(A∩C)A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)A∩(B∪C)=(A∩B)∪(A∩C)
(A∪B)c=Ac∩Bc(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c(A∪B)c=Ac∩Bc
(A∩B)c=Ac∪Bc(A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c(A∩B)c=Ac∪Bc
A∪ϕ=AA \cup \phi = AA∪ϕ=A
A∩ϕ=ϕA \cap \phi = \phiA∩ϕ=ϕ

Probability
Let SSS be a sample space. A function PPP defined on events of SSS is called a probability measure if it satisfies:
Axiom 1. 0≤P(A)≤10 \leq P(A) \leq 10≤P(A)≤1
Axiom 2. P(S)=1P(S) = 1P(S)=1
Axiom 3. If A1A_1A1​, A2A_2A2​, … is a sequence of pairwise disjoint events, then P(A1∪A2...)P(A_1 \cup A_2 ...)P(A1​∪A2​...) = P(A1)+P(A2)+...P(A_1) + P(A_2) + ...P(A1​)+P(A2​)+...
4. We can show that P(ϕ)=0P(\phi) = 0P(ϕ)=0

Result: P(A1∪A2∪...∪An)=∑i=1P(Ai)P(A_1 \cup A_2 \cup ... \cup A_n) = \sum_{i=1} P(A_i)P(A1​∪A2​∪...∪An​)=∑i=1​P(Ai​) if they are pairwise disjoint.
Proof:
Define Ai=ϕ,i≥n+1A_i = \phi, i \geq n+1Ai​=ϕ,i≥n+1 then Ai∩Aj=ϕ,∀i≠jA_i \cap A_j = \phi ,\forall i \neq jAi​∩Aj​=ϕ,∀i̸​=j
∑i=1∞P(Ai)=∑i=1nP(Ai)+∑n+1∞P(Ai)\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(A_i) = \sum_{i=1}^{n}P(A_i) + \sum_{n+1}^{\infty}P(A_i)∑i=1∞​P(Ai​)=∑i=1n​P(Ai​)+∑n+1∞​P(Ai​)

Theorem of total probability
Let A1,A2,A3...A_1, A_2, A_3...A1​,A2​,A3​... be a partition of SSS and BBB is any event in SSS, then P(B)=P(B∩A1)+P(B∩A2)+...P(B) = P(B\cap A_1) + P(B \cap A_2) + ...P(B)=P(B∩A1​)+P(B∩A2​)+...
Proof:
B=∪i=1∞(B∩Ai)B = \cup_{i=1}^{\infty}(B \cap A_i)B=∪i=1∞​(B∩Ai​)
B∩AiB\cap A_iB∩Ai​ are pairwise disjoint.
P(B)=P(∩i=1∞(B∩Ai))=∑i=1∞P(B∩Ai)P(B) = P(\cap_{i=1}^ {\infty}(B\cap A_i)) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} P(B \cap A_i)P(B)=P(∩i=1∞​(B∩Ai​))=∑i=1∞​P(B∩Ai​)

Definition

If AAA and BBB are any two events of SSS
A∖B=A∩BcA \setminus B = A \cap B^cA∖B=A∩Bc
P(A∖B)=P(A)−P(A∩B)P(A \setminus B) = P(A) - P(A \cap B)P(A∖B)=P(A)−P(A∩B)
Proof:
Note that A=(A∖B)∪(A∩B)A = (A \setminus B) \cup (A \cap B)A=(A∖B)∪(A∩B) and these two are disjoint.
P(A)=P(A∖B)+P(A∩B)P(A) = P(A \setminus B) + P(A \cap B)P(A)=P(A∖B)+P(A∩B) since sum of union is the sum of probabilities.
P(A∖B)=P(A)−P(AB)P(A \setminus B) = P(A) - P(AB)P(A∖B)=P(A)−P(AB)

Result

If A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B then P(A)≤P(B)P(A) \leq P(B)P(A)≤P(B)
Proof: P(B∖A)=P(B)−P(AB)P(B \setminus A) = P(B) - P(AB)P(B∖A)=P(B)−P(AB)
=P(B)−P(A)≥0= P(B) - P(A) \geq 0=P(B)−P(A)≥0 by first axiom.
P(A)≤P(B)P(A) \leq P(B)P(A)≤P(B)

Result

P(Ac)=1−P(A)P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)P(Ac)=1−P(A)
Proof: Ac=S∖AA^c = S \setminus AAc=S∖A
P(Ac)=P(S∖A)P(A^c) = P(S \setminus A)P(Ac)=P(S∖A)
=P(S)=P(S∩A)=P(S) = P(S \cap A)=P(S)=P(S∩A)
=1−P(A)=1 - P(A)=1−P(A)

Lecture 2

Result
If AAA and BBB are any two events in a sample space SSS, then P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B)−P(A∩B)
Proof
A∪B=A∪(B∖A)A \cup B = A \cup (B \setminus A)A∪B=A∪(B∖A)
P(A∪B)=P(A∪(B∖A))P(A \cup B) = P(A \cup (B \setminus A))P(A∪B)=P(A∪(B∖A))
=P(A)+P(B∖A)= P(A) + P(B \setminus A)=P(A)+P(B∖A)
=P(A)+P(B)−P(AB)= P(A) + P(B) - P(AB)=P(A)+P(B)−P(AB)

Note: P(A∪B)≤P(A)+P(B)P(A \cup B) \leq P(A) + P(B)P(A∪B)≤P(A)+P(B)
Note: For any collection of events, A1,A2,...,AnA_1, A_2, ..., A_nA1​,A2​,...,An​, P(∪i=1n)≤∑i=1nP(Ai)P(\cup_{i=1}^{n}) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{n}P(A_i)P(∪i=1n​)≤∑i=1n​P(Ai​)

Result
For any three events A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C in the sample space SSS, P(A∪B∪C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)−P(AB)−P(AC)−P(BC)+P(ABC)P(A \cup B \cup C) = P(A) + P(B) + P(C) - P(AB) - P(AC) - P(BC) + P(ABC)P(A∪B∪C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)−P(AB)−P(AC)−P(BC)+P(ABC)
Proof
P(A)+P(B∪C)−P(A∩(B∪C))P(A) + P(B \cup C) - P(A \cap (B \cup C))P(A)+P(B∪C)−P(A∩(B∪C))
=P(A)+P(B∪C)−P(AB∪AC)=P(A) + P(B \cup C) - P(AB \cup AC)=P(A)+P(B∪C)−P(AB∪AC)
=P(A)+[P(B)+P(C)−P(BC)]−[P(AB)+P(AC)−P(ABC)]=P(A) + [P(B) + P(C) - P(BC)] - [P(AB) + P(AC) - P(ABC)]=P(A)+[P(B)+P(C)−P(BC)]−[P(AB)+P(AC)−P(ABC)]
=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)−P(AB)−P(AC)−P(BC)+P(ABC)= P(A) + P(B) + P(C) - P(AB) - P(AC) - P(BC) + P(ABC)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)−P(AB)−P(AC)−P(BC)+P(ABC)

Example
Among 33 students in a class 17 earned A’s on the midterm exam, 14 earned A’s on the final exam. 11 of them did not earn A’s on either exam. What is the probability that a randomly selected student from this class earned A’s on both exams.
P(M)=1733P(M) = \frac{17}{33}P(M)=3317​
P(F)=1433P(F) = \frac{14}{33}P(F)=3314​
P(M∪F)=P(M)+P(F)−P(M∩F)P(M \cup F) = P(M) + P(F) - P(M \cap F)P(M∪F)=P(M)+P(F)−P(M∩F)
2233−1733−1433\frac{22}{33} - \frac{17}{33} - \frac{14}{33}3322​−3317​−3314​
933\frac{9}{33}339​
311\frac{3}{11}113​

Uniform Probability Measure on finite sample spaces.
Let SSS be a finite sample space with equally likely outcomes and let AAA be any event in SSS, then the uniform probability measure is given by P(A)=∣A∣∣S∣P(A) = \frac{|A|}{|S|}P(A)=∣S∣∣A∣​.
Note: This is a probability measure.

  1. 0≤P(A)≤10 \leq P(A) \leq 10≤P(A)≤1
  2. P(S)=∣S∣∣S∣=1P(S) = \frac{|S|}{|S|} = 1P(S)=∣S∣∣S∣​=1
  3. Trivial exercise xd

Lecture 3

Counting Combinations
The number of combinations of kkk objects from nnn objects is (nk)n\choose k(kn​) = n!k!(n−k)!\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}k!(n−k)!n!​ The number of ways of dividing nnn objects into two groups of sizes n1n_1n1​ and n2n_2n2​ = n!n1!n2!\frac{n!}{n_1!n_2!}n1​!n2​!n!​

The number of ways of dividing a group of nnn objects into kkk groups of sizes n1,n2...nkn_1, n_2 ... n_kn1​,n2​...nk​ is n!n1!n2!...nk!\frac{n!}{n_1!n_2!...n_k!}n1​!n2​!...nk​!n!​ = (nn1,n2,n3...nk)n\choose n_1,n_2,n_3...n_k(n1​,n2​,n3​...nk​n​)

Example: A student prepares for an exam by studying 10 questions. For the exam the instructor selects 5 questions. The student can solve 6 of the 10 questions. What is the probability that the student can solve the questions?

(65)(105)\frac{6\choose 5}{10 \choose 5}(510​)(56​)​

Example: A deck of 52 cards contains 12 picture cards. If 52 cards are distributed among 4 players, s.t each player gets 13 cards, what is the prob that each player will get 3 picture cards?

(123,3,3,3)(4010,10,10,10)(5213,13,13,13)\frac{{12 \choose 3,3,3,3}{40\choose 10,10,10,10}}{52\choose 13,13,13,13}(13,13,13,1352​)(3,3,3,312​)(10,10,10,1040​)​

Example: One of my classes has 60 students. John and Jane are two students in the class. I want to divide the class into two groups at random. What is the probability that John and Jane will be in the same group?

2∗(5829)(6030)2*\frac{58 \choose 29}{60 \choose 30}2∗(3060​)(2958​)​

Conditional Probability

Definition: Let AAA and BBB be two events in a sample space SSS. Then the conditional probability of AAA given BBB is defined by P(A∣B)=P(AB)P(B)P(A | B) = \frac{P(AB)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(AB)​

Example: If AAA and BBB are events s.t P(A)=0.5,P(B)=0.3,P(AB)=0.1P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.3, P(AB) = 0.1P(A)=0.5,P(B)=0.3,P(AB)=0.1.
P(A∣B)=0.10.3P(A | B) = \frac{0.1}{0.3}P(A∣B)=0.30.1​
P(B∣A)=0.10.5P(B | A) = \frac{0.1}{0.5}P(B∣A)=0.50.1​
P(A∣(A∪B))=0.50.5+0.3−0.1P(A | (A \cup B)) = \frac{0.5}{0.5+0.3-0.1}P(A∣(A∪B))=0.5+0.3−0.10.5​
P(A∣AB)=1P(A | AB) = 1P(A∣AB)=1
P(AB∣(A∪B))=0.10.5+0.3−0.1P(AB | (A \cup B)) = \frac{0.1}{0.5+0.3-0.1}P(AB∣(A∪B))=0.5+0.3−0.10.1​

Note: Conditional probability is a probability measure.
P(A∣B)=P(X∣B)P(A|B) = P( X | B)P(A∣B)=P(X∣B)
P(S∣B)=1P(S|B) = 1P(S∣B)=1
P(A1∪A2∪...An)=P(A1∣B)+...+P(An∣B)P(A_1 \cup A_2 \cup ... A_n) = P(A_1 | B) + ... +P(A_n | B)P(A1​∪A2​∪...An​)=P(A1​∣B)+...+P(An​∣B)

Axiom 1
Note: AB⊆BAB \subseteq BAB⊆B
P(AB)P(B)≤P(B)P(B)\frac{P(AB)}{P(B)} \leq \frac{P(B)}{P(B)}P(B)P(AB)​≤P(B)P(B)​
0≤P(A∣B)≤10 \leq P(A|B) \leq 10≤P(A∣B)≤1

Axiom 2
P(S∣B)=P(SB)P(B)=1P(S|B) = \frac{P(SB)}{P(B)} = 1P(S∣B)=P(B)P(SB)​=1

Axiom 3
Let A1,A2,...A_1, A_2, ...A1​,A2​,... be a countable collection of disjoint events.
P(A1∪A2...∣B)P(A_1 \cup A_2 ... |B)P(A1​∪A2​...∣B)
=P((A1∪A2...)∩BP(B)= \frac{P((A_1 \cup A_2...) \cap B}{P(B)}=P(B)P((A1​∪A2​...)∩B​
Note: AiBiA_iB_iAi​Bi​ are disjoint.
=P(A1B)P(B)+...= \frac{P(A_1B)}{P(B)} + ...=P(B)P(A1​B)​+...
=P(A1∣B)+...= P(A_1 | B) + ...=P(A1​∣B)+...

Theorem of total probability (conditional)
Let A1,A2...A_1, A_2 ...A1​,A2​... be a partition of S.
Then P(B)=P(B∣A1)P(A1)+P(B∣A2)P(A2)+...P(B) = P(B | A_1)P(A_1) + P(B|A_2)P(A_2) + ...P(B)=P(B∣A1​)P(A1​)+P(B∣A2​)P(A2​)+...

Bayes Theorem
Let AAA and BBB be any two events in SSS. Then P(A∣B)=P(A)P(B)∗P(B∣A)P(A|B) = \frac{P(A)}{P(B)} * P(B|A)P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A)​∗P(B∣A).

Example: A population of voters contains 40% republicans and 60% democrats. It is reported that 30% of the republicans and 50% of the democrats favor an election issue. A person chosen at random favors the issue. What is the probability that this voter is a democrat?

P(R)=25P(R) =\frac{2}{5}P(R)=52​
P(D)=35P(D) = \frac{3}{5}P(D)=53​

P(F∣R)=0.3P(F|R) = 0.3P(F∣R)=0.3
P(F∣D)=0.5P(F|D) = 0.5P(F∣D)=0.5

P(D∣F)=P(D)P(F)∗P(F∣D)P(D|F) = \frac{P(D)}{P(F)} * P(F | D)P(D∣F)=P(F)P(D)​∗P(F∣D)

Lecture 4

Independent Events
Two events AAA and BBB in SSS are independent if and only if P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B)P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B). Also P(A∣B)=P(A)P(A | B) = P(A)P(A∣B)=P(A).

Example: Roll a die: A={1,3,5}A = \{1, 3, 5\}A={1,3,5} B={2,4,6}B = \{2, 4, 6\}B={2,4,6} C={1,2}C = \{1, 2\}C={1,2}
a) AAA and BBB are not independent, since P(A∩B)≠P(A)P(B)P(A \cap B) \neq P(A)P(B)P(A∩B)̸​=P(A)P(B)
b) AAA and CCC are independent.

Note: If AAA and BBB are two events s.t P(A)&gt;0,P(B)&gt;0P(A) &gt; 0, P(B)&gt;0P(A)>0,P(B)>0, and if AAA and BBB are disjoint, then AAA and BBB are not independent.

A⊥B→A⊥BcA \perp B \rightarrow A \perp B^cA⊥B→A⊥Bc
P(ABc)=P(A)−P(AB)P(AB^c) = P(A) - P(AB)P(ABc)=P(A)−P(AB)
=P(A)−P(A)P(B)= P(A) - P(A)P(B)=P(A)−P(A)P(B)
=P(A)(1−P(B))=P(A)(1 - P(B))=P(A)(1−P(B))
=P(A)P(Bc)=P(A)P(B^c)=P(A)P(Bc)

Note: A⊥B→Ac⊥BcA \perp B \rightarrow A^c \perp B^cA⊥B→Ac⊥Bc

The events A1,A2...AnA_1, A_2 ... A_nA1​,A2​...An​ in SSS are independent if P(Ai1∩Ai2∩...Aik)=P(Ai1)P(Ai2)...P(Aik)P(A_{i1} \cap A_{i2} \cap ... A_{ik}) = P(A_{i1})P(A_{i2})...P(A_{ik})P(Ai1​∩Ai2​∩...Aik​)=P(Ai1​)P(Ai2​)...P(Aik​) for each finite subset.

Example: Roll a fair 4-sided die. S={1,2,3,4}S = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}S={1,2,3,4}. A={1,2}A = \{1, 2\}A={1,2} B={1,3}B = \{1, 3\}B={1,3} C={1,4}C = \{1, 4\}C={1,4}
a) A⊥BA \perp BA⊥B
b) B⊥CB \perp CB⊥C
c) A⊥CA \perp CA⊥C
d) All the events together are not independent.

Lecture 5

Continuity Theorem of Probability
{An}⇑Aor{An}⇓A\{A_n\} \Uparrow A or \{A_n\} \Downarrow A{An​}⇑Aor{An​}⇓A then P(A)lim⁡n→∞P(An)P(A) \lim_{n \to \infty}P(A_n)P(A)limn→∞​P(An​)

Case 1:
{An}↑A\{A_n\} \uparrow A{An​}↑A
A=∪n=1∞An=A1∪(∪i=2∞Ai∖Ai−1)A = \cup_{n=1}^{\infty}A_n = A_1 \cup (\cup_{i=2}^{\infty} A_i \setminus A_{i-1})A=∪n=1∞​An​=A1​∪(∪i=2∞​Ai​∖Ai−1​)
P(A)=P(A)+P(∪i=2∞Ai∖Ai−1)P(A) = P(A) + P(\cup_{i=2}^{\infty} A_i \setminus A_{i-1})P(A)=P(A)+P(∪i=2∞​Ai​∖Ai−1​) are disjoint.
=P(A1)+∑i=2∞P(A∖Ai−1)=P(A_1) + \sum_{i=2}^{\infty}P(A \setminus A_{i-1})=P(A1​)+∑i=2∞​P(A∖Ai−1​)
=P(A1)+lim⁡n→∞∑i=2nP(A∖Ai−1)=P(A_1) + \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=2}^{n}P(A \setminus A_{i-1})=P(A1​)+limn→∞​∑i=2n​P(A∖Ai−1​)
=P(A1)+lim⁡n→∞∑i=2nP(A)−P(Ai−1)=P(A_1) + \lim_{n \to \infty}\sum_{i=2}^{n}P(A) - P(A_{i-1})=P(A1​)+limn→∞​∑i=2n​P(A)−P(Ai−1​)
=lim⁡n→∞P(An)=\lim_{n \to \infty}P(A_n)=limn→∞​P(An​)

Case2:
{An}↓A\{A_n\} \downarrow A{An​}↓A
Let Bn=AncB_n = A_n^cBn​=Anc​ then {Bn}\{B_n\}{Bn​} is an increasing sequence.
{Bn}↑Ac\{B_n\} \uparrow A^c{Bn​}↑Ac
By case 1, P(Ac)=lim⁡n→∞P(Bn)P(A^c) = \lim_{n\to \infty} P(B_n)P(Ac)=limn→∞​P(Bn​)
1−P(A)=lim⁡(1−P(An))1-P(A) = \lim(1-P(A_n))1−P(A)=lim(1−P(An​))
P(A)=lim⁡AnP(A) = \lim A_nP(A)=limAn​

Example:
Suppose S={1,2,3,...}S = \{1, 2, 3,...\}S={1,2,3,...} PPP is defined by P(s)=2−sP({s}) = 2^{-s}P(s)=2−s
Find P({5,6,7}P(\{5, 6, 7\}P({5,6,7} using continuity theorem.
Define An={5,6,7,..,n}A_n = \{5, 6, 7, .., n\}An​={5,6,7,..,n}
An↑AA_n \uparrow AAn​↑A
P(A)=P({5,6,...})=lim⁡n→∞P(An)P(A) = P(\{5, 6, ...\}) = \lim_{n \to \infty}P(A_n)P(A)=P({5,6,...})=limn→∞​P(An​)

Random Variables and their Distributions

Definition: Random variable: A random variable is a function from the sample space to the set of real numbers.
Ex: Toss a coin S={H,T}S=\{H, T\}S={H,T}

Definition: Distribution of a r.v XXX
The collection of probabilities P(x∈B)P(x \in B)P(x∈B) for all B⊆RB \subseteq RB⊆R is called a distribution of a random variable XXX.

Discrete Random Variables
A random variable XXX is discrete if there is a finite or countably infinite sequence of real numbers x1,x2,...,xnx_1, x_2, ... , x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​ and a corresponding sequence of positive real numbers p1,p2,...,pnp_1, p_2, ... , p_np1​,p2​,...,pn​ such that P(X=xi)=piP(X = x_i) = p_iP(X=xi​)=pi​ and ∑pi=1\sum p_i = 1∑pi​=1.

Probability Mass function of discrete random variables
The probability mass function (pmf) of a discrete random variable XXX is the function Px:R→[0,1]P_x : R\rightarrow [0,1]Px​:R→[0,1] defined by Px(x)=P(X=x)P_x(x) = P(X = x)Px​(x)=P(X=x)

P_x | 1/6 1/6 1/6 1/6 1/6 1/6
P(X∈{5,6})=13=pX(5)+pX(6)=∑x∈{5,6}pX(x)P(X \in \{5, 6\}) = \frac{1}{3} = p_X(5) + p_X(6) = \sum_{x \in \{5, 6\}} p_X(x)P(X∈{5,6})=31​=pX​(5)+pX​(6)=∑x∈{5,6}​pX​(x)
Note: For B⊆R,P(X∈B)=∑x∈BpX(x)B \subseteq R,P(X \in B) = \sum_{x\in B} p_X(x)B⊆R,P(X∈B)=∑x∈B​pX​(x)

  3. Binomial Distribution
    A r.v is said to have a binomial distribution with parameters nnn and θ\thetaθ
    if pX(x)=(nx)θx(1−θ)n−x,x=0,1,2,...np_X(x) ={n \choose x}\theta^x(1-\theta)^{n-x}, x = 0, 1, 2, ... npX​(x)=(xn​)θx(1−θ)n−x,x=0,1,2,...n.
  4. Geometric Distribution
    A r.v XXX is said to have a geometric distribution with parameter θ\thetaθ
    (X∼geometric(θ))(X \sim geometric(\theta))(X∼geometric(θ)) if pX(x)=(1−θ)xθ,x=0,1,2,...p_X(x) = (1-\theta)^x\theta, x = 0, 1, 2, ...pX​(x)=(1−θ)xθ,x=0,1,2,...

Density Function
A function f:R→Rf: R \rightarrow Rf:R→R is called a density function if it satisfies:

  1. f(x)≥0,∀x∈Rf(x) \geq 0, \forall x \in Rf(x)≥0,∀x∈R
  2. ∫−∞∞f(x)dx=1\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f(x)dx = 1∫−∞∞​f(x)dx=1

Absolutely Continuous Random Variables
A random variable XXX is said to be absolutely continuous if there exists a density function fff such that P(a≤X≤b)=∫abf(x)dxP(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_{a}^{b}f(x)dxP(a≤X≤b)=∫ab​f(x)dx whenever a≤ba \leq ba≤b
Note: Abs cts rvs are cts, converse is false.

Cumulative Distribution Functions
For a given r.v XXX the function FX:R→[0,1]F_X : R \rightarrow [0, 1]FX​:R→[0,1] defined by FX(x)=P(X≤x)F_X(x) = P(X \leq x)FX​(x)=P(X≤x) is called the cdf of XXX

Properties of FxF_xFx​

  1. 0≤FX(x)≤10 \leq F_X(x) \leq 10≤FX​(x)≤1
  2. a≤b→FX(a)≤FX(b)a \leq b \rightarrow F_X(a) \leq F_X(b)a≤b→FX​(a)≤FX​(b)
  3. lim⁡x→+∞FX(x)=1\lim_{x \to +\infty} F_X(x) = 1limx→+∞​FX​(x)=1
  4. lim⁡x→−∞FX(x)=0\lim_{x \to -\infty} F_X(x) = 0limx→−∞​FX​(x)=0
  5. P(a&lt;X≤b)=FX(b)−FX(a)P(a &lt; X \leq b) = F_X(b) - F_X(a)P(a<X≤b)=FX​(b)−FX​(a)
  6. P(a≤X≤B)=FX(b)−lim⁡n→∞FX(a−1n)P(a \leq X \leq B) = F_X(b) - \lim_{n \to \infty} F_X(a - \frac{1}{n})P(a≤X≤B)=FX​(b)−limn→∞​FX​(a−n1​)
  7. P(X∈(a,b))=FX(b−)−FX(a)P(X \in (a, b)) = F_X(b-) - F_X(a)P(X∈(a,b))=FX​(b−)−FX​(a)
  8. P(X∈[a,b])=FX(b−)−FX(a−)P(X \in [a, b]) = F_X(b-)-F_X(a-)P(X∈[a,b])=FX​(b−)−FX​(a−)

Joint distributions
Let XXX and YYY be 2 r.vs. The set of all probabilities P((x,y)∈B),b⊆R2P((x,y) \in B), b \subseteq R^2P((x,y)∈B),b⊆R2 is called the joint distribution of XXX and YYY.
(x,y)∈B={s:(X(s),Y(s))∈B}(x, y) \in B = \{s: (X(s), Y(s)) \in B\}(x,y)∈B={s:(X(s),Y(s))∈B}

Joint cdf
Let XXX and YYY be r.vs. The joint cdf of XXX and YYY is the function Fx,y:R2→[0,1]=P(X≤x,Y≤y)F_{x,y}: R^2 \rightarrow [0,1] =P(X \leq x, Y\leq y)Fx,y​:R2→[0,1]=P(X≤x,Y≤y)

Conditional Distributions
Let XXX and YYY be jointly discrete random variables. Then for any xxx such that P(X=x)&gt;0P(X=x) &gt; 0P(X=x)>0, the conditional distribution of YYY given X=xX =xX=x is the collection of probabilities P(Y∈B,X=x)P(X=x)∀B⊆R\frac{P(Y \in B, X = x)}{P(X = x)} \forall B \subseteq RP(X=x)P(Y∈B,X=x)​∀B⊆R
In particular, this assigns probability P(a&lt;Y≤b,X=x)P(x=x)\frac{P(a &lt; Y \leq b, X=x)}{P(x=x)}P(x=x)P(a<Y≤b,X=x)​

Conditional mass function:
Let XXX and YYY be jointly discrete with joint mass function pxyp_{xy}pxy​ and let x∈Rx \in Rx∈R be st P(X=x)&gt;0P(X=x) &gt; 0P(X=x)>0, then the conditional mass function of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is given by:

Let XXX and YYY be jointly abs acts with joint pdf fXYf_{XY}fXY​ and marginal pdfs fxf_xfx​, fyf_yfy​, then for xxx s.t fX(x)&gt;0f_X(x) &gt; 0fX​(x)>0, the conditional distribution of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is defined by the prob P(a≤Y≤b∣X=x)=∫abfY∣X(y∣x)dyP(a \leq Y \leq b | X = x) = \int_{a}^{b}f_{Y|X} (y|x) dyP(a≤Y≤b∣X=x)=∫ab​fY∣X​(y∣x)dy

Independence of r.vs
2 rvs XXX and YYY are said to be independent if P(X∈B1,Y∈B2)=P(X∈B1)P(Y∈B2)∀B1,B2⊆RP(X \in B_1, Y \in B_2) = P(X \in B_1)P(Y \in B_2) \forall B_1, B_2 \subseteq RP(X∈B1​,Y∈B2​)=P(X∈B1​)P(Y∈B2​)∀B1​,B2​⊆R

rvs XXX and YYY are independent iff P(a≤X≤b,c≤Y≤d)=P(a≤X≤b)P(c≤Y≤d)P(a \leq X \leq b, c \leq Y \leq d) = P(a \leq X \leq b)P(c\leq Y \leq d)P(a≤X≤b,c≤Y≤d)=P(a≤X≤b)P(c≤Y≤d)

If XXX and YYY are jointly discrete then X⊥YX \perp YX⊥Y iff pXY(x,y)=pX(x)pY(y)p_{XY}(x, y) = p_X(x)p_Y(y)pXY​(x,y)=pX​(x)pY​(y)

If XXX and YYY are jointly abs cts, then X⊥YX \perp YX⊥Y iff fXY(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y)f_{XY}(x,y) = f_X(x)f_Y(y)fXY​(x,y)=fX​(x)fY​(y)

Expectation
If XXX is a discrete r.v with pmf fXf_XfX​, then the expectation of XXX, sometimes called the mean of XXX or the expected value of XXX, is defined by E(X)=∑xxpX(x)E(X) = \sum_{x}xp_X(x)E(X)=∑x​xpX​(x)

Suppose that a power series has radius of convergence R, converges on (C−R,C+R)(C-R,C+R)(C−R,C+R).

X∼Degenerate(c)→E(X)=cX \sim Degenerate(c) \rightarrow E(X) = cX∼Degenerate(c)→E(X)=c
X∼Ber(θ)→E(X)=θX \sim Ber(\theta) \rightarrow E(X) = \thetaX∼Ber(θ)→E(X)=θ
X∼Bin(n,θ)→E(X)=nθX \sim Bin(n, \theta) \rightarrow E(X) = n\thetaX∼Bin(n,θ)→E(X)=nθ
X∼Geo(θ)→E(X)=1−θθX \sim Geo(\theta) \rightarrow E(X) = \frac{1-\theta}{\theta}X∼Geo(θ)→E(X)=θ1−θ​
X∼Poisson(λ)→E(X)=λX \sim Poisson(\lambda) \rightarrow E(X) = \lambdaX∼Poisson(λ)→E(X)=λ

Covariance
Definition: if XXX and YYY are two r.vs, then covariance of XXX and YYY is defined by Cov(X,Y)=E[(X−μX)(Y−μY)]Cov(X,Y) = E[(X-\mu_X)(Y-\mu_Y)]Cov(X,Y)=E[(X−μX​)(Y−μY​)]
E[XY]−E(X)E(Y)E[XY] - E(X)E(Y)E[XY]−E(X)E(Y)

Cov(X,Y)=Cov(Y,X)Cov(X,Y) = Cov(Y,X)Cov(X,Y)=Cov(Y,X)
Cov(X,a+bY)=bCov(X,Y)Cov(X, a+bY) = bCov(X,Y)Cov(X,a+bY)=bCov(X,Y)
X⊥Y→Cov(X,Y)=0X \perp Y \rightarrow Cov(X,Y) = 0X⊥Y→Cov(X,Y)=0

Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y)+2Cov(X,Y)Var(X+Y) = Var(X) + Var(Y) + 2Cov(X, Y)Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y)+2Cov(X,Y)

Var(∑i=1nXi)=∑i=1nVar(Xi)+2∑i∑jCov(Xi,Xj)Var(\sum_{i=1}^nX_i) = \sum_{i=1}^nVar(X_i) + 2\sum_i\sum_jCov(X_i, X_j)Var(∑i=1n​Xi​)=∑i=1n​Var(Xi​)+2∑i​∑j​Cov(Xi​,Xj​)

If they are independent then the variance of the sums is the sum of the variances.

Correlation
For r.v XXX and YYY, the correlation of XXX and YYY is given by Corr(X,Y)=Cov(X,Y)Var(X)Var(Y)Corr(X, Y) = \frac{Cov(X,Y)}{\sqrt{Var(X)Var(Y)}}Corr(X,Y)=Var(X)Var(Y)​Cov(X,Y)​

If Y=a+bXY = a + bXY=a+bX Corr(X,Y)=b∣b∣Corr(X,Y) = \frac{b}{|b|}Corr(X,Y)=∣b∣b​

Inequalities
Markov’s inequality:
If XXX is a non-negative r.v then for any a&gt;0a &gt; 0a>0 then P(X&gt;a)≤E(X)aP(X &gt; a) \leq \frac{E(X)}{a}P(X>a)≤aE(X)​

Chebyshev’s inequality:
For any r.v XXX, s.t V(X)&lt;∞V(X) &lt; \inftyV(X)<∞
P(∣X−μX∣≥a)≤V(X)a2P(|X-\mu_X| \geq a) \leq \frac{V(X)}{a^2}P(∣X−μX​∣≥a)≤a2V(X)​

Cauchy-Schwartz inequality
If XXX and YYY are 2 r.vs,
(E(XY))2≤E(X2)E(Y2)(E(XY))^2 \leq E(X^2)E(Y^2)(E(XY))2≤E(X2)E(Y2)

Random Sample
A collection of iid r.vs from some distribution is called a random sample from that distribution.

Statistic
Any function of a random sample is called a statistic.

The distribution of a statistic is called the sampling distribution of that statistic.

Convergence in probability.
Let X1,X2,...X_1, X_2, ...X1​,X2​,... be a sequence of r.vs, then we say that XnX_nXn​ converges to XXX in probability if for any ϵ&gt;0\epsilon &gt; 0ϵ>0, lim⁡n→∞P(∣Xn−X)≥ϵ)=0\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} P(|X_n - X) \geq \epsilon) = 0limn→∞​P(∣Xn​−X)≥ϵ)=0

Lecture 24

Weak law of Large numbers
Let X1,X2,...X_1, X_2, ...X1​,X2​,... be independent rvs with the same mean and V(Xi)≤vV(X_i) \leq vV(Xi​)≤v, then Mn=∑i=1nXinM_n = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_i}{n}Mn​=n∑i=1n​Xi​​ converges in probability to μ\muμ.

Convergence in distribution

Let X1,X2...X_1, X_2...X1​,X2​... be a sequence of r.vs and XXX is a random variable. We say {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​} converges to XXX in distribution if lim⁡n→∞P(Xn≤x)=P(X≤x)∀x,s.tP(X=x)=0\lim_{n \to \infty}P(X_n \leq x) = P(X \leq x) \forall x ,s.tP(X=x)=0limn→∞​P(Xn​≤x)=P(X≤x)∀x,s.tP(X=x)=0

Central Limit Theorem

Let X1,X2...X_1, X_2...X1​,X2​... be iid random variables. with finite mean E(Xi)=μE(X_i) = \muE(Xi​)=μ and finite variance Var(Xi)=σ2Var(X_i) = \sigma^2Var(Xi​)=σ2.
Zn=Mn−μσnZ_n = \frac{M_n - \mu}{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}}Zn​=n​σ​Mn​−μ​ converges to Z∼N(0,1)Z \sim N(0,1)Z∼N(0,1)
